cons: Nothing I don't have. I don't have a lunch break

pros: My managers are amazing and allowed for growth throughout my tenure @ LGC. They are amazing! I have a lot of autonomy and am able to work on projects that are super interesting. Management is really flexible and seem committed to professional development for employees!
cons: The only downside is that a lack of interaction with other departments, but given COVID its understandable.

pros: Pretty easy work, decent amount of downtime
cons: Didn’t feel too challenged at times

pros: Project areas are impactful and hugely important. Our work truly makes a difference in California.
cons: The organization has grown so much that there were operational growing pains still in the process of being addressed and improved.

pros: community, professional development, equity, climate action, diverse projects
cons: stipend, monthly tasks, short timeframe, undergraduate degree required

pros: Enough time to set up your own business
cons: No opportunity for growth and development

pros: Great organizational culture; flexible work policies; engaged and committed team
cons: Salaries are low compared to other similar NGOs

pros: A very supportive and career-oriented program that provides high-level experience for recent college graduates seeking "real" (read: important) experience in the sustainability field. There are lots of opportunities for technical training and extensive resources for future positions after the service year. There is also an education award through AmeriCorps that can be used for either student debt or further education.
cons: Although it is no secret, the pay is low. Additionally, cost of living adjustments (raises) are based on where one's project site is, not where one lives, which can put fellows serving in low-income locations at a disadvantage. The allowed vacation/sick time is also less than most full-time positions.

pros: The LGC staff are great. I felt very supported throughout the service year. I learned a lot from this year about government and am very glad I did the program.
cons: At my placement site, I wasn’t given as much direction. My manager was often overwhelmed and didn’t have time to review my work products.

pros: LGC is a mission driven organization committed to fostering positive social and environmental change in California. The CivicSpark program that they run, of which I am a Fellow, has exceeded my expectations
cons: I don't have any about LGC specifically. But as a CivicSpark Fellow I will say that the pay is brutal.

pros: Excellent opportunity to work within local government to provide capacity building on important environmental issues related to climate adaptation and water resource management.
cons: AmeriCorps stipend is very low and a challenge.

job_title: Civicspark Water Fellow in Culver City, CA
pros: Webinars, regional trainings, and other resources are provided to ensure you are on the right path (resumes workshops, webinars on equity, etc.)
cons: There is a low salary, its called a service year so low pay.

pros: Most of the people are great.  Good benefits and PTO
cons: Very religious atmosphere and they make you feel weird and different about not being like them.

pros: Great place to build your network and skills as a young professional!
cons: Of course, the main downside of being in AmeriCorps is the pay.

pros: opportunity to grow professionally; high caliber projects
cons: internal processes need to be updated for projects to run smoothly
